description:
Example of a Selectable Local Kafka Dashboard for DC/OS 1.12

- For Developers: Parameterized to an input-able Kafka Cluster Name
- Only displays metrics for Brokers and Topics within a specified Kafka cluster

panels.description: Average messages per second per Topic
panels.title: Cluster avg msg/sec (1m) by Topic

panels.description: Average messages per second per Topic
panels.title: Cluster avg msg/sec (5m) by Topic

panels.description: Average messages per second per Topic
panels.title: Cluster avg msg/sec (15m) by Topic

panels.description: Number of leaders on this broker. This should be mostly even across all brokers. If not, set auto.leader.rebalance.enable to true on all brokers in the cluster.
panels.title: Number of Leaders per Broker

panels.description: Number of partitions on this broker. This should be mostly even across all brokers.
panels.title: Partition Count Across Brokers

panels.description: The first node to boot in a Kafka cluster automatically becomes the controller, and there can be only one. The controller in a Kafka cluster is responsible for maintaining the list of partition leaders, and coordinating leadership transitions (in the event a partition leader becomes unavailable). If it becomes necessary to replace the controller, a new controller is randomly chosen by ZooKeeper from the pool of brokers. In general, it is not possible for this value to be greater than one, but you should definitely alert on a value of zero that lasts for more than a short period (< 1s) of time.
panels.title: ActiveControllerCount

panels.description:
In a healthy cluster, the number of in sync replicas (ISRs) should be exactly equal to the total number of replicas. If partition replicas fall too far behind their leaders, the follower partition is removed from the ISR pool, and you should see a corresponding increase in IsrShrinksPerSec. Since Kafkaâ€™s high-availability guarantees cannot be met without replication, investigation is certainly warranted should this metric value exceed zero for extended time periods.

If this metric has a value greater than 1 it means that data is not being replicated to enough number of brokers thereby increasing the probability of data loss.
panels.title: Under Replicated Partitions

panels.description: The first node to boot in a Kafka cluster automatically becomes the controller, and there can be only one. The controller in a Kafka cluster is responsible for maintaining the list of partition leaders, and coordinating leadership transitions (in the event a partition leader becomes unavailable). If it becomes necessary to replace the controller, a new controller is randomly chosen by ZooKeeper from the pool of brokers. In general, it is not possible for this value to be greater than one, but you should definitely alert on a value of zero that lasts for more than a short period (< 1s) of time.
panels.title: Total Partition Count per Broker

panels.description: This value should be 0
panels.title: Offline Partitions per Broker

panels.title: Kafka avg msg/sec (15m) per Broker

panels.description: Generally, disk throughput tends to be the main bottleneck in Kafka performance. However, thatâ€™s not to say that the network is never a bottleneck. Depending on your use case, hardware, and configuration, the network can quickly become the slowest segment of a messageâ€™s trip, especially if you are sending messages across data centers. Tracking network throughput on your brokers gives you more information as to where potential bottlenecks may lie, and can inform decisions like whether or not you should enable end-to-end compression of your messages.
panels.title: All Bytes In (1min) per Broker
